channel.title: [Help] PHP/MySQL to flash
channel.description:
I'm not the best with php and MySQL. What I'm trying to do here is have users register on a site. After registering, they would proceed to play my flash game and login. The point of registering is to connect to a MySQL database while playing the flash game, and it saves your player data as you go on. I've got it connected correctly, but I don't know how to make a login/register system :(
This is how something is inserted to the database: INSERT INTO data (name, password, distance) VALUES ($username, $password, 0) [The ID is auto-incremented, so it's not added into this]
When the person logs in via php, it needs to POST the username, and that it was a valid login. This makes it possible for Flash to pick up the variable.

item.title: [Help] PHP/MySQL to flash
item.dc:creator: @justaguy justaguy
item.description:
@justaguy wrote:

[quote=“Bellend, post:4, topic:517988”][quote author=Ruby link=topic=636251.msg4292195#msg4292195 date=1367516369]
I highly suggest not using that code at all, it’s insecure and deprecated, but he has the right idea :).
[php]

<?php include('./includes/db.connection.php'); $username = $_POST['username']; $con = new mysqli($host, $user, $pass, $db); $stmt = $con->prepare("INSERT INTO tbl_name (username) VALUES (?); $stmt->bind_param("s", $username); $stmt->execute() or die($stmt->error); $stmt->close(); [/php] Would be an example of secure code to use, [b]never[/b] trust user input. Not meaning to sound like a dick towards Bellend (pardon the pun :P) but I wouldn't want your site being vulnerable. [/quote] he asked for a way on how to do this, not how to make it secure. If i were to spend time securing the code i would be here for hours. Plus i'm not here to do the work for him. a way for you to make sure people can't inject you is to just escape the string with this function "mysql_real_escape_string($STRING)" that way the user input will not affect the process.[/quote] Securing code isn't hard when you know what you're doing and decide to stop being lazy. The time it takes to secure a simple form is as long as it takes to write out the necessary function(s) in the code. I agree with Ruby; don't post vulnerable code.

item.title: [Help] PHP/MySQL to flash
item.dc:creator: @Bellend Bellend
item.description:
@Bellend wrote:

Ok, so insted of updating the Database directly from flash (and having to use a DLL service) you are best of just using php requests

so make a new webrequest in flash to a file like so: “www.sitename.com/requests/SavePlayer.php?name=” + PlayerName
PlayerName is a variable that your flash game will hold

then the php file will look something like this

<?php
if(isset($_GET['name'])) {
    $UName = $_GET['name'];
}else{
    $UName = "";
}

$Query = "INSERT INTO tablename (Username, Column2) VALUES ('$UName', 'Something')"; //this will set the query into a variable string
mysql_query($Query); //this will call the string as a query and run it into your database
echo mysql_error(); //this will print any errors if you have any...

?>
